title: Wildcat Trail Newtonmore Walking Route

images.title: Donald Noble / Wildcat Trail at Strone
images.caption: Wildcat Trail at Strone. Walking along the trail around Newtonmore, looking towards Creag Mhòr, Loch Gynack and Creah Bheag in the distance.

images.title: Mark Thomas / Glen Banchor
images.caption: Glen Banchor Looking up Glen Banchor. The river in the foreground is the River Calder, with Creag Liath in the background. Taken from a viewpoint on the Wildcat Trail.

images.title: Jim Barton / Ford and footbridge
images.caption: Ford and footbridge. On the Allt na Feithe Buidhe; the track leads up to a water supply reservoir.

images.title: Mick Garratt / Confluence of the Rivers Spey and Calder
images.caption: Confluence of the Rivers Spey and Calder

images.title: Mark Thomas / Allt Laraidh flowing into the Spey
images.caption: Allt Laraidh flowing into the Spey

images.title: Mark Thomas / River Calder
images.caption: River Calder. A view of the River Calder where it flows through a deep gorge west of Newtonmore. The river is flowing right to left.

images.title: March Cairn by ronnie leask, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: March Cairn

images.title: Pictish Hut Circle by ronnie leask, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Pictish Hut Circle

description: This is a super circular walk around the village of Newtonmore in the Cairngorms National Park. The 10km route is fairly easy with little climbing and is waymarked throughout with a wildcat symbol. There are lovely waterside sections along the great River Spey and River Calder. You will also pass a splendid gorge and a waterfall with magnificent views of the Cairngorm & Monadhliath Mountains for the duration of the walk.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: For more walking ideas in the area see the Cairngorms Walks page.
